If people are confused about the canons:

Halloween (1978) & Halloween 2 (2018)- Michael and Lorie are NOT established to be brother and sister and Lorie's children Jamie from Halloween 4,5,6 and John from Halloween 7 (Jamie didn't exist in 7) do not exist in this movie canon.  


Halloween 1, Halloween 2 and H20 are canon to each other. - Michael and Lorie ARE established to be long-lost brother and sister. In h20, John is Lorie's only child, Jamie doesn't exist in this canon. 

Halloween 1,2,4,5,6 are canon to each other.- in this canon, Jamie is Lorie's only child and Steven her only grandchild. John doesn''t exist in this canon because Lorie died in a car crash off-screen. 

Hope this helps with any confusion :)

Halloween 2 takes place on the same night but itâ€™s not canon. This is said in the trailer since it is mentioned that Laurie is not his sister and also that he only killed 3 people and thatâ€™s it. The only thing that is confusing is how he was arrested right after the first movie since he was shot 6 times by Dr. Loomis and then his body disappeared meaning he escaped. Supposedly they are ignoring the continuity that says that he is immortal so him disappearing after being shot that many times makes no sense. Oh and Iâ€™m actually kind of happy that they are ignoring the second movie and Laurie being his sister because that gets rid of the ridiculous coincidence that is their connection. Now itâ€™s just some random psychotic killer which is actually better for the story because it really makes him the boogeyman.

Sadly this looks very poor and generic to me. I was four years old when Halloween 1978 was released and started my love of Horror movies. When I look at this trailer the atmosphere is so out to place. I mean come on....a S Carolina shoot is a poor go and does nothing for the feel of the film. Jamie Lee Curtis may be in this one but the way she is presenting is questionable and I think the story line is choppy and full of holes that will only disappoint the fans in the end. Blumhouse has yet to impress me with any of their films and this one seems to be no different. Maybe I am the only one as most comments I am reading seem to be happy and that is Okay. I am much older now and maybe expectations run different among younger audiences. I guess this is the Halloween catered to a new generation. I do hope the movie well and I still plan to see it but not expecting much. I will only be out of $20 and 2 hours of my time and if it exceeds my expectations then I will be pleasantly surprised. Hopefully another upcoming director will come forward and do it justice eventually as an old fan like me hopes to see but until then we shall await October. Wow. This is one of those films which looks as though it will live up to the hype it's built. As a long time fan I have been wanting to see this franchise put to rest given they took things too far beyond absurd. So, to me having Laurie Strode face down Michael who as it turns out ISN'T her brother is great. I know many a fan are pissed that this ignores everything after part one, however, I fully understand why the decision was made to have it be so. 

The sibling connection along with the whole bloody curse of thorn bit got old fast. And while I did enjoy parts 2, 3, and 4, it all went exponentially downhill after 4. And Rob Zombie's shitty remake and sequel only added salt to the wound. This looks as though they're taking things back to basics as it were with suspense, relying less on gore and shock, and giving it the same vibe as the original. I love the fact that Laurie has known in her heart for years that he'd come back, and she's been ready. 

Plus she has family of her own to protect from him, and that makes it even more interesting. I really hope this is the end of the franchise, and they choose not to milk it any further. I feel giving it a tried and true proper send off is the best decision.
Finally,

I keep forgetting Michael's killing spree in the original was basically 4 people and two dogs. The babysitters, the one boyfriend and the guy in the truck who he stole the jumpsuit from plus the dog Michael ate and the Lindsey's dog who found a "hot date". It kinda shows you how far slasher movies have come, and how they have basically made life and death appear trivial. Each one of those lives in the original meant something before Michael took them. In subsequent sequels each character who died meant less and less and less.

I still don't like how he isn't her brother. I get that it retains the purity of the original but it still feels odd after the second movie (and H20). The original can stand alone as its own self contained entity where they aren't siblings, or you can view their relationship as siblings after the second one. But going back again and acting like the second never happened is annoying in a way. (6/8/18)

So, we now have three distinct "Halloween" canons that all have the same movie included:

Canon 1: Part 1-2 + 3-6
Canon 2: Part 1-2 + H20 + Resurrection
Canon 3: Part 1 + this one

So, if you like the original, but don't like the supernatural Thorn stuff from the sequels, there's another official series for you.
And if you think the "I am your brother" revelation is already stupid, you now have yet another series that even disregards part 2.

I wish they would have done this with "A Nightmare on Elm Street": A closing sequel where ONLY the first movie is acknowledged as canon, where part 2-6 + FvJ never happened and where Freddy was never able to collect souls or where he's not the wisecracking joker, but only slightly sarcastic, but otherwise not much of a talker.

I've seen some comments about how the brother / sister connection being tossed doesn't make sense because then Michael wouldn't have an incentive to go back for Laurie.  I think that's not the case at all.  I think Michael is just on the mindset of "kill," and the only reason he happens to run into Laurie again is because SHE is chasing him.  Once she finds him again he might re-target her, but if she didn't chase him down I don't think he would've necessarily gone straight for her.  Remember, the way he was originally crafted by John Carpenter was that he had no sentiment.  He had no true thought processes of his own, unless they were to stalk & kill.  Once he has escaped, he can only do so, no more, no less.  He's an extremely simple being, which arguably makes him scarier, and the story of the original sequels seemed to forget that.

I have a few problems with this movie.. 

If Michael was captured after Loomis shot him, that kills the ending of the original movie. Unless he just gets caught down the street or something, but that would be even worse. 

Michael being 61 years old also bugs me. How can he possibly be Michael Myers at that age? I'm sure it won't harm the movie, but I wish he wasn't a senior citizen. 

Another issue is that the last time Laurie Strode was put back into the spotlight we got H20 which was a bad movie. Its praise is mind-boggling. Hopefully this time she takes a lesser role. I don't mind her being there but I don't want the finale to be the clash of old people. 

All that aside, I ultimately like what I see. A lot. I love Halloween and things just haven't been right for a long time. Maybe this movie will finally bring some credibility back to the name. Either way, it's just really nice to see another Halloween film.

I find some of the comments to the trailer so utterly frustrating, and so completely lacking in understanding of PTSD.  Laurie Strode, 40 years ago was stalked by an escaped mental patient.  Michael Myers killed 2 of her best friends, Annie and Lynda, along with Lynda's boyfriend Bob, then staged their bodies for Laurie to find, like some kind of haunted house.  He then attacked her and injured her.  She then had to defend the two children in her care, while also trying to defend herself.  After stabbing him with a knitting needle, coat hanger, and his own butcher knife, she finally gets the kids to safety and is only saved herself by Michael's own therapist, who shoots him 6 times, causing him to fall of a second floor balcony, and even then he survives and walks away, and we now know was caught and put back in lock-down, the very type of environment he escaped from once before.  

Laurie Strode lost not only two close friends, but from what we saw in the first film, they were the yin to her yang, they were outgoing and adventurous, while she was shy and apprehensive.  They were the type of friends who push you to do things you otherwise likely wouldn't do on your own.  Laurie through this loss, likely became isolated, and lived many years after the first film in fear.  People have different ways of coping with the fear of PTSD, one of which is to become fixated on the cause, and to take steps to, in the case of PTSD caused by being a victim of some event in the past, go out of their way to prepare to ensure what happened before can't happen again.  Laurie was meek, easily scared, and defenseless in the first film, a person who obsesses on ensuring what happened in the past can't happen again would become exactly what Laurie has become.

Could she have chosen to leave Haddonfield, maybe, we don't know the circumstances of her financial means, and other various things that would have dictated such actions.  Also to consider, her remaining friends and family, most of them anyways, still live in the area.  We don't know what she's been through.  All we know, is that some point, fear turned to anger, and that anger turned to obsession with preparing for what she believed was inevitable.  Regardless of whether she stayed by choice, or more out of obligation, or if maybe she did leave for a time, but chose or was obligated to come back, she chose to face her fears head on, instead of being consumed and paralyzed by them.  She chose to prepare for what she believed would inevitably happen, that he would return.

She chose, whether fortunate or unfortunate for her, wisely.

I'm getting a good feeling about this, because it's highlighting Micheal Meyers being a fucking weirdo.

The original Halloween became so famous because of good cinematography that made Micheal out to be a silent, demonic predator. He appeared in places he wasn't supposed to in unexplained ways, watched people silently from far away before vanishing from a jump cut, and the jump scares were carefully crafted through just how creepy it was.

I feel like this film is going for that angle, instead of "Strong guy in mask stabs teenagers" from the films that followed.

This is going to be amazing. I love the way they're going to be incorporating the original into this one for the new generation. This franchise is transcending time, a direct sequel 40 years later. For the kids in the movie that may be affected, I believe Michael is coming back to murder teenage babysitters - again. Hence the reason there's a kid in the trailer - think Tommy Doyle - the BOOGEYMAN. This will create a new legend in the story for a new generation. The Halloween franchise has always been about the 6 year old boy from Haddonfield, Illinois who on Halloween night back in 1963 murdered his teenage sister in cold blood. He was sent to Smith's Grove - Warren County Sanitarium where he escaped 15 years later and killed 3 teenagers - 1 of which was a babysitter. Another babysitter survived and her name is Laurie Strode. The night HE came home!

Finally, after 40 years, and relentless amounts of mediocre attempts of making Michael Myers a b-horror movie staple. I get what looks like an honest attempt at recreating the cinematic magic that was John Carpenter's Magnum Opus. I suppose, recreating will not do justice here. An attempt at honorably continuing on something that has changed the entire course of cinema. Movies like these are not meant to be approached lightly, but with ambition. David Gordon Green has taken upon him a daunting task, which looks to be a valorous effort. 

It may not be 1978, greatest horror movie of all time, great. But it can be a solid close out to the most iconic Horror movie of all time. A valiant coming home story of a Psycho, and a traumatized aged baby sitter, squaring off for legacy.

In my opinion, the film's biggest asset is Jamie Lee and the music. It's biggest apparent weakness is a possible attempt to modernize Halloween, which has already been attempted by Rob Zombie and clearly failed. If the cast's goal is to remain true to the original Halloween film -- which the cast has stated several times --  then cold camera filters reminiscent of "Saw" (like the one used in the bathroom scene) and unnecessary gory motifs (dropping teeth paired with cheesy acting) have no place in this film. I am supportive of their attempt to re-ignite this franchise, but there have been over ten terrible Halloween films since the 1978 original. And I am not interested in seeing any more, especially after Rob Zombie's modern adaptations.

I understand the choice to have it a sequel to the first and not have Michael be related BUT I struggle a bit to find Laurie's motivation to be prepared for his return. Really in the first film she barely has interaction with Michael, summed up to be about 30 mins being persued by a man in a Mask only to be shot and disappear. If its been 40 years I don't know how committed she would have been to this cause and be ready for an unknown stranger that attacked her on Halloween Night

At the very least, if they kept the relationship cannon, she'd know that Michael is always thinking of his sister, that there may be a chance he'll come for her, that drove her motivation in H2O always knowing he could be there and always having to look over her shoulder, that gave H2O its charm, the eerie notion that my brother is going to come for me, to remove that and it be just a stranger...hmmm I struggle a bit I have to admit.

Then I thought well if it was a sequel to Halloween 2, atleast Michael's determination would have been there to keep coming for his sister, the only work around to that would be the burning of Michael's body at the end but really they could have retreaded Halloween 4's beginning with him being transported.

I'm definitely looking forward to seeing what they''re going to do with this one, again Laurie's obsession for preparing for Michael at least from the trailer end of it seems a bit of a stretch, the audience knows what the characters have been through in the 7 movies or so BUT this is a woman readying herself not really so that she's never scared and attacked by someone again but specifically for one man that tried to kill her one time when she was a teenager, kinda wish for that reason this was a sequel to H2O and not to just the first film, then we would have established Laurie's drive and what lengths she'll go through
i just dont understand why they're ignoring Halloween 2, i mean i understand ignoring H20 and Resurrection, but yeah makes no sense. kinda dumb, still looking forward to this one.

Yep, I'll be in theatres DAY ONE!!! Feels like Michael Myers is back to his good old scary roots: an unknown being with no motivation whatsoever. Maybe this time it's a bit more "unfinished business" but it's nice to know it's not "family matters" anymore. It was okay, but it took away the essence of Michael: mystery, creepiness, horror and overall scariness.

On another note: the mask looks like it "aged" rather than "decayed", which is an extra creepy point. I hope they don't explain why (and since Mr. Carpenter is executive producing, I'm pretty sure he made sure the mystery would be intact).

Let's clear this up:  Danny McBride chose not to include the second film because it established Laurie as his sister.  It was only decided to make Laurie his sister after the success of the original movie.  The decision to make her his sister was made because 1.) they didn't want the "babysitter killer" story to get old and 2.) Jamie Lee Curtis made her character Laurie so compelling that they needed an excuse to bring her back for the sequel...  

For the 2018 movie, Danny McBride chose to exclude the sibling relationship because he felt it made Michael less terrifying.  If his primary motivation for killing is just to kill his sister, it gives the audience a sense of security, knowing they will be safe as long as they stay away from his relatives.  I was disappointed by this because I love the journey Laurie's character takes in the original franchise, going from a real victim suffering from PTSD to a strong survivor who faced her fears (minus the god awful Halloween Resurrection).  But then after watching the 2018 trailer, I instantly looked over my shoulder in paranoia, so Danny's choice worked...  

Another disappointment of mine is disregarding all of the other films.  Don't get me wrong:  With the exception of Halloween 1, 2, and H20, the rest are pretty shitty (in my opinion).  But I HATE discontinuity.  I'd rather work hard to clean up and wrap up a declining franchise than just "reboot" it.  A reboot-sequel (I know this movie is NOT a full reboot) like this usually satisfies dedicated fans, but confuses new viewers who aren't familiar.

My only lasting disappointment is the removal of the supernatural element. And I'm not talking about the dumb backstory that Michael has to kill his family as some sacrifice.  I'm talking about Carpenter's original description of Michael as "The Shape;" this raw insatiable shark-like evil that will stop at nothing to kill her.  A darkness that can't be reasoned with.  I don't want him to be invincible, but someone stronger than the strongest man and more animalistic than any animal.  While I only like Halloweens 1, 2, and H20, I do like how the evil essence of Michael is an unkillable energy that can be passed on after his death (like to his niece Jamie in Halloween 4).  Sadly, serial killers are a dime a dozen, so they'll have to work hard to separate Michael Myers from the rest.

For people who are a tad confused about this film, allow me to break it down for you. This Halloween is the sequel to the original Halloween by John Carpenter, taking place 40 years after the original film in which Michael Myers was apprehended presumably after he ran off after he was shot by Loomis. This film retcons every single sequel following that ending which means Laurie Strode and Michael Myers are no longer siblings. 

Also for those thinking this film will receive sequels, you're dead wrong. Jamie Lee Curtis and John Carpenter are intending this to be the last showdown between Laurie and Michael and finally give a definitive ending to the Halloween franchise, that's the only reason they wanted to make this film. So take it all in because this trailer, this event is a once in a lifetime opportunity to go witness one of horror's greatest icons on the big screen. This looks like it's going to be amazing and as someone who never got to witness Halloween, I'm going to enjoy this immensely.

In October of 1978, I was a junior in high school.  My friends and I went to see the original Halloween movie on its Friday night opening. I will never forget that there were people leaving their seats and heading towards the back of the theater and then standing there to continue watching it.  They were so scared.  Halloween, like JAWS, is a classic scare movie.  What is impressive about the original film is that there is not a single drop of blood shown from Michaelâ€™s killings.  No gore factor like the SAW films.  Just pure scare.  40 years later, I cannot wait to see this follow-up story.  Jamie Lee Curtis looks like she is going to kick some serious ass!  Ellen Ripley and Laurie Strode!  Kiss Ass Bitches!!

The only reason Carpenter wrote that Laurie and Michael were siblings in Halloween 2 was because of writer's block. He himself has stated that he regretted that decision as it took away from the mystery of Michael Myers. Because what you don't know is always scarier. So that's why this is a direct sequel to the original and also in order for Michael to appear more human and less of a supernatural being that he was in the sequels.

Just to make things clear for some of the people that are confused.

Laurie Strode is alive because this takes place after the 1978 movie. It's a direct sequel to the original. None of the other movies matter here. They're making it that Michael was captured that night, 40 years ago, and he's been in prison ever since.

This is going to change some of the mythos of the story. Him being this type of supernatural immortal being is gone, along with him being Laurie's brother.
